Award.AwardTitle: Fully Nonlinear Elliptic Equations and Related Geometric Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal concerns fully nonlinear elliptic equations that arise from or have strong connections with problems in geometry. It focuses on three topics: estimates for fully nonlinear elliptic equations on real or complex manifolds; asymptotic Plateau problems in hyperbolic space; and questions on regularity and weak solutions of the complex Monge-Ampere equation. These topics are all closely related, with the strong common feature that most of the major questions are centred at or reduce to establishing certain a priori estimates for solutions of some fully nonlinear partial differential equations. Yet each of these questions presents unique technical challenges.

Fully nonlinear elliptic equations play key roles in understanding difficult problems in mathematics, and have important applications such as in image processing, optical reflector designs, optimal mass transport, and mathematical physics. A central issue in order to solve a fully nonlinear second order equation is to establish a priori estimates for perspective solutions. Our goal is to search for techniques to derive such estimates under conditions which are close to optimal for general elliptic (but not assumed uniformly elliptic) equations on real or complex manifolds. Breakthroughs in this direction would have broad impacts to the whole field of fully nonlinear PDEs and their applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we study fully nonlinear elliptic and parabolic partial differential equations on real or complex manifolds. These equations naturally occur and play critical roles in many branches of mathemtics and other fields., particulally in differetial geometry, conformal geometry, and complex geometry. We were able to slove the Dirichlet problem for a wide class of fully nonlinear equations on general Riemannian or Hermitian manifolds, and establish regularity results for equations on closed manifolds under essentially optimal conditions. We introduced new ideas and and developed important techincal tools in our work which have proved useful in the study of interesting problems from geometry. 

      An central issue in the study of fully nonlinear partial differential equations is to derive a priori estimates up to second order for perspective solutions, which is especially challeging for equations on general Riemannian manifolds or, in the complex case, Hermitian manifolds, in comparison to whose defined in real or complex Euclidean spaces. The main difficulties arise from at least two aspects; one is due to the highly linear nature of the equations and the other becuase of the complexity of geometry of a genaral underlying manifold, as well as its arbitrary boundary to which we wish to impose no geometric restrictions form the application point of view. We were able to overcome these difficuties and established the second order estimates . Among our new contributions, we made use of subsolutions in a crtitcal way to derive the global estimates, as well as the concavity condition of the equation based on newly discovered property of concave or convex functions which obviously will find interesting applications in control theory, optimization problems, as well as other areas concerning convex fucntions. Our method have been used by other researchers to study important geometric problems. 


Last Modified: 11/01/2017
Modified by: Bo Guan
